learning_outcomes.description: Understand the importance of the contemporary media environment in public relations including the emerging role of AI.
Identify the importance of effective targeting to reach important publics and audiences;
Develop effective written, oral and visual communication skills for owned, earned and shared media;
Learn how to combine a range of media skills and techniques to achieve the best outcome;
Learn the importance of creativity, innovation and good writing in modern media strategy;
Learn the importance of relationship management and ethical and legal practice in media management;
Understand the links between theory and practice;
Work, learn and problem solve independently

assessments.task_description:
Aim: Each student develops a media planning portfolio of four items in response to a client brief, which will be provided in class by an external client. This portfolio will include:

  1. A plan on a page that outlines an overall response to the client issue or problem based on the use of the ROPE model (research, objectives, tactics and evaluation).
  2. A brief overview (one page) of elements to be included in a press conference plan (e.g. invited journalists, location, timing etc).
  3. A media alert (one page) inviting media to the proposed press conference.
  4. A media release (one to two pages) detailing the proposed announcement at the press conference.


Overview: In media work "to be most effective, we need to have a plan" (Johnston & Rowney 2018, p. 109). This assessment calls on various elements of strategic planning to ensure an efficient and successful media outcome.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. Alternatively, students must also note if they have not used AI or MT. Students must use university approved format which will be provided on the course Blackboard. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Your plan must be uploaded to TurnItIn with a cover sheet including word length. Cover sheet (including AI disclosure statement) is not included in word count.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The visual media outputs include:

  1. A 90 second video
  2. An infographic embedded within that video (can be still or motion)
  3. A post production video script using the class-assigned, four column format


The visual media should respond to the planning portfolio, particularly the plan on a page. It should consider organisational style -- this includes fonts, colour palettes, format as outlined in the client brief. The infographic should include a footnote and the video should include acknowledgement of source material (e.g. music and sound effects). All video should be original and

Workshops on Premiere Pro for video development will be held by MaPS and you are encouraged to enrol and attend. Please enrol early as places are limited. For students who miss a place, a range of dedicated video links are posted in resources and available on BB. Lectures, BB materials, chapters and tutorials cover various aspects of the plan and asset development. 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. Alternatively, students must also note if they have not used AI or MT. Students must use university approved format which will be provided on the course Blackboard. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission of the asset portfolio as follows:
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
An end of semester exam will be scheduled within the exam block. The exam will consist of multiple choice, a media release writing task and a short reflection on AI use in the media strategies.

One page of notes will be allowed.

The exam will be held under closed exam conditions with no access to the internet. Students are advised that the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) will therefore be prohibited.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Inspera Assessment will be used for this invigilated on-campus digital assessment and students in this course will complete this using their own device. Details about Inspera Assessment, including an introduction to Inspera functionality and where to go for support, are available here: https://elearning.uq.edu.au/student-guides-original/inspera-assessment-original
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
